thread.title: Jacoby Ellsbury’s baby arrives, and then he does | New York Post
thread.title_full: Jacoby Ellsbury’s baby arrives, and then he does | New York Post

author: George A. King III
title: Jacoby Ellsbury’s baby arrives, and then he does | New York Post
text:
TAMPA — Jacoby Ellsbury checked into camp Tuesday after his arrival was delayed for two days due to the birth of his second child.
General manager Brian Cashman and manager Joe Girardi have said they would like more from Ellsbury , who is in the fourth leg of a seven-year deal worth $153 million. In three seasons with the Yankees, Ellsbury has hit .264, which is 22 points below his career mark.
“As far as being where he is at, we will watch him the next few days,’’ Girardi said of the 33-year-old center fielder. “Obviously he is a couple of days behind. His wife is great, the baby is great, and that is what I talked about [Tuesday]. Physically he looked good.’’
Senior vice president of MLB’s baseball operations Peter Woodfork met with Girardi. Girardi and Cashman also met with Rich Rieker, the director of umpiring development for MLB.
With talk of rule changes regarding pace of game, Girardi was asked if that subject was discussed.
“Because of the Collective Bargaining Agreement taking so long, there is nothing instituted, but it’s possible some of these things could be instituted before the season starts,’’ Girardi said. “I don’t think it’s fair that I share because I don’t know what is going to happen. All of them don’t get passed.’’
SEE ALSO 
Masahiro Tanaka starts his poker face on biggest Yankees call 0:0 TAMPA — Among the biggest storylines on any team in... Last spring training, Masahiro Tanaka was coming back from having a bone spur removed from his right arm and was brought along slowly. This year, there are no limits on the Yankees’ ace, who has been very crisp in bullpen sessions and anointed the Opening Day starter for the third straight season.
Tuesday, Tanaka threw 26 pitches in a bullpen session and was sharp with most of them. His first spring start will be next Tuesday.
Pitchers Ronald Herrera and James Reeves are shelved with injuries. Herrera has inflammation in the right shoulder and will be out two weeks. Reeves has a mild sprain of the ligament in his left elbow. He is expected to be out three-to-four weeks.
The Yankees dealt lefty reliever Richard Bleier to the Orioles for a player to be named or cash. Bleier was in camp with the Yankees before being designated for assignment.
